The parliament voted on July 06, 2020 in favour of the 6th extension of the state of health emergency in the DRC - this would extend the state of health emergency for an additional 15 days. This state of emergency has been in place since March 24th. Schools remain closed and only distance learning is happening.      http://web.archive.org/web/20200709162532/https://www.politico.cd/grand-angle/2020/07/08/lecole-a-lheure-de-la-covid-19-la-reprise-des-enseignements-cest-pour-aujourdhui-appelle-pascal-mpia-mena-zambili.html/64348/  http://web.archive.org/web/20200709162339/https://www.politico.cd/la-rdc-a-la-une/2020/07/06/assemblee-nationale-la-pleniere-adopte-la-6eme-prorogation-de-letat-durgence.html/64249/  http://web.archive.org/web/20200706174343/https://www.politico.cd/la-rdc-a-la-une/2020/07/06/prorogation-de-letat-durgence-sanitaire-tunda-ya-kasende-empeche-son-adjoint-bernard-takahishe-defend-le-projet-de-loi.html/64243/

No change in policy - border closure remains in place for all international passengers with the exception of repatriation of Congolese nationals and foreigners in DRC who wish to leave.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200713204902/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
State of emergency is still in place. Schools and universities remain closed (no change)    http://web.archive.org/web/20200716201736/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

State of emergency is still in place. Sporting events and gatherings larger than 20 people are banned, bars and restaurants are closed until further notice. Non-food stores in Kinshasa were ordered closed.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200716201736/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

State of emergency is still in place. Sporting events and gatherings larger than 20 people are banned, bars and restaurants are closed until further notice.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200716201736/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

State of emergency is still in place. Sporting events and gatherings larger than 20 people are banned, bars and restaurants are closed until further notice.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200716201736/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

State of emergency is still in place. All domestic passenger flights between Kinshasa and the provinces remain suspended.  All road and river transport between Kinshasa and the provinces remain suspended for passenger traffic.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200716201736/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
State of emergency is still in place. Suspension of international passenger flights remains in place.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200716201736/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No further announcements on workplaces - social distancing highly recommended

I have, by Executive Instrument, provided for these new directions, and extended the suspension of the remaining public gatherings, as set out in E.I. 64 of 15th March, until 31st July. In here, I refer to the suspension of sporting events, nightclubs, cinemas, drinking spots, bars, beaches, festivals, funerals, political rallies, and large religious gatherings such as crusades, pilgrimages and conventions."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200604215546/http://www.presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1597-update-no-10-measures-taken-to-combat-spread-of-coronavirus

The cessation of movement order that barred entry into and out of Nairobi, Mombasa and Mandera counties lapsed on July 7th.  Any movement by public transport vehicles into and out of these areas requires transport providers to first acquire mandatory certification from the Ministry of Health, in consultation with the Ministry of Transport. Users of public or private transport are required to wear a protective mask.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200713150952/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All measures that were put in place on June 5, 2020 when the Liberian Leader announced some modifications to the COVID-19 guidelines remain in effect. See https://web.archive.org/web/20200623004545/https://www.emansion.gov.lr/2press.php?news_id=5165&related=7&pg=sp

On June 22, 2020, the President of Liberia announced a 30-day extension of restrictions, with some revisions, intended to halt the spread of COVID-19 in the country. This means that restrictions remain in place till July 22, including that all are required to be indoors by 6 pm instead of the previous 9 pm timeframe. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20200623004545/https://www.emansion.gov.lr/2press.php?news_id=5165&related=7&pg=sp

All measures that were put in place on June 5, 2020 when the Liberian Leader announced some modifications to the COVID-19 guidelines remain in effect. See https://web.archive.org/web/20200623004545/https://www.emansion.gov.lr/2press.php?news_id=5165&related=7&pg=sp. Measures included: Movement to and from counties not yet affected by COVID-19 will be restricted. With the exception of basic supplies, all other such movements between/amongst counties are prohibited. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20200715105845/https://emansion.gov.lr/2press.php?news_id=5159&related=7&pg=sp

It seems like the ban was lifted on June 28th. Note: Liberiaâs Roberts International Airport opened on June 28th to commercial flights, even though the country remains in a state of emergency until July 22.  All passengers will be required to have their temperature taken for symptoms of COVID-19 and register via phone numbers/USSD Mobile App.    All arriving passengers who have been tested at point of departure must present a valid negative result document on arrival at RIA.    All arriving passengers who have not been tested at point of departure will be required to take a rapid test and a PCR swab at airport.  a.  In the event of a positive rapid test result, the passenger will be placed in the holding unit at the airport pending the final PCR test result.  b. Passengers having negative test results will be allowed to go home pending final PCR test. See https://web.archive.org/web/20200715110724/https://lr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Bank of Mauritius is extending the access period to its 5 billion rupee ($130 million) special relief programme as part of its ongoing response to the Covid-19 pandemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200712182653/https://www.centralbanking.com/central-banks/monetary-policy/7653846/bank-of-mauritius-extends-covid-19-support-measures

The National Bank of Mauritus is extending the following measures of its COVID-19 Relief programme:  -The Bank of Mauritius has introduced a Special Relief through commercial banks to meet cash flow and working capital requirements of economic operators which are being directly impacted by COVID-19. This Special Relief Amount is being made available, through commercial banks up to 30 September 2020, to all sectors of activities impacted by COVID-19, including SMEs.  - Disbursements will be effected through commercial banks and the Bank of Mauritius is capping interest on these advances to impacted economic operators at the fixed rate of 1.5 per cent per annum.  - The repayment period is extended from 30 months to 48 months, with a moratorium period of up to 9 months.  -  Impacted operators are invited to contact their respective commercial banks.  -The Bank of Mauritius introduced on 23 March 2020 a USD/MUR swap arrangement with commercial banks for an initial amount of USD100 Million.  - This arrangement aims at enabling commercial banks to support import-oriented businesses, except for the State Trading Corporation which will be dealing directly with the Bank of Mauritius for its foreign currency requirements until further notice.  - The Bank has increased the amount for swap transactions by an additional USD100 Million.  - This facility, which was initially effective until 30 June 2020, will now be available to banks for the next 6 months.  -The Bank has now raised the amount of the FX line of credit to banks for funding purposes from USD300 Million to USD500 Million, that is, by an additional amount of USD200 Million.  -The additional amount will be available to banks for the next 6 months.  -The facility will be repayable one ( 1) year from the effective date of disbursement.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200713215936/https://www.marketscreener.com/news/Bank-of-Mauritius-Support-Programme-Extension-of-specific-measures--30917301/
https://web.archive.org/web/20200714034439/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/namibia/coronavirus  FCO travel advice  There are no commercial flights to and from Namibia.

Motos are allowed to carry passengers, under appropriate social distancing and strict hygiene.     /web/20200717033949/https://twitter.com/PrimatureRwanda/status/1283523263302426628

Movement in previously locked down Rusizi district shall resume, but movement between this region and the outside is restricted.   /web/20200717033949/https://twitter.com/PrimatureRwanda/status/1283523263302426628

Effective July 8, the government of Sudan has authorised the reopening of shops, restaurants, and limited government services.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200717143100/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/07/sudan-begins-easing-coronavirus-lockdown-measures-200708151450416.html

The Government of Sudan has authorised public transportation to restart operating as of July 8, 2020. Restrictions continue to apply during curfew hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200717135543/https://sd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of July 8 the Government of Sudan has moved to a 6:00pm to 6:00am curfew in Khartoum. All persons are able to move freely, including across bridges, from 6:00am to 6:00pm local time.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200717135543/https://sd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Effective July 13, the government of Sudan has authorised the partial reopening of the Khartoum International Airport to international flights (from Egypt, Turkey, and the United Arab Emirates).   https://web.archive.org/web/20200717132145/https://sd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Since Monday 13th of July, "all mosques, churches, and other places of worship shall be open for congregation and worship" announced by the President on 10th of July on his twitter account.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200716182837/https://twitter.com/PresidentBio/status/1281323023711248384

Though Sudan eased down its restrictions from 8th July but it does not include opening of educational institutions at any level.  Linkhttps://web.archive.org/web/20200715155329/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-07/10/c_139201145.htm

Many shops reopened their doors for customers, while some companies resumed normal operation in Khartoum, though few customers showed up due to the public transport restrictions.  Linkhttps://web.archive.org/web/20200715155329/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-07/10/c_139201145.htm

Many shops reopened their doors for customers, while some companies resumed normal operation in Khartoum, though few customers showed up due to the public transport restrictions.  Note :The above statement shows that, despite the fact that restrictions have been eased down, public transport restrictions are still there.  Linkhttps://web.archive.org/web/20200715155329/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-07/10/c_139201145.htm
Lockdown restrictions have been eased down. but people are recommended to stay at home.  Link:https://web.archive.org/web/20200715155329/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-07/10/c_139201145.htm

In his recommendations, the minister urged restricting the movement of people and vehicles between the country's 18 states, excluding the movement of commodities and sick people in emergency cases.  Linkhttps://web.archive.org/web/20200715155329/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-07/10/c_139201145.htm

Al-Tom demanded continued closure of Sudan's borders and crossings, and the full curfew in Khartoum with reducing the period of movement within the neighbourhoods by two hours.  Linkhttps://web.archive.org/web/20200715155329/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-07/10/c_139201145.htm
